items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: High river levels this evening, 13 January 2026, into tonight may lead to flooding. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Church Laneham to Rampton Road. There is no further rainfall forecast today, however there is more rainfall forecast on Thursday, 15/01/2026. River levels at Torksey Gauge are rising slowly and expected to remain high until 15/01/2026. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated after 09:00AM tomorrow morning, 14 January 2026, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent rainfall and snow melt. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.

River levels at Pillings Lock Gauge will remain high over the next few days. There is minimal further rainfall forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation & checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 09:00AM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Flooding is expected. 

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected on the River Cherwell especially near Enslow, Thrupp and Kidlington. The high river levels are due to the heavy rainfall we saw on Thursday 8 January. The water has now made its way down the river. The weather forecast today (Tuesday 13 January) and tomorrow is mostly dry, with a few showers in places. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 12:00PM, midday, on the 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 12:00PM, midday, on the 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. Flood water is receding from the causeway at Sutton Gault. This information is correct as of 08:00 on 13 January 2026. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. There are currently no issues on the Welney and Earith causeways. 
If you have been evacuated only return to your property once the emergency services have advised that it is safe to do so. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.message:
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Semington Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.
Weather conditions are expected to remain unsettled throughout Tuesday and Wednesday, with a heavier band of rain forecast on Thursday (although this has a lower confidence being 3 days away currently). Whilst the rivers have started to rise, they haven't risen as much as initially forecast yesterday. The flood alert level is now forecast to be met again this afternoon therefore the flood alert will remain in force.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Rising river levels this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 13 January 2026 . 
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Water Lane and Lingfield. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 13 January 2026 from 18:00. 15mm of rain has fallen, with 5mm forecast. 
Minor flooding could affect Hammer Lane, Grove Hill, and gardens of Mill Lane, Hellingly. From 20:00 13/01/2026 minor flooding could affect gardens on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. From 02:00 14/01/2026 minor flooding could affect fields near North Street, River Lane, and The Old Clergy House, Alfriston. Rain should ease by 06:00 14/01/2026. River levels should peak lower than 09/01/2026. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 15:00 14/01/2026 in Hellingly, and 23:00 14/01/2026 in Alfriston. Rain on Thursday has the potential to cause property flooding. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood (Mill Ln Church Rd Hellingly, North St Alfriston). 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Wednesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 14 January 2026 from 06:00, following 15mm of rain on Tuesday. 
Minor flooding could affect gardens of properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham, and near Fittleworth Mill. In Liss, river levels are already beginning to peak. Only minimal flood impacts affecting fields are expected between Liss and Midhurst. Almost no rain is forecast Tuesday evening and Wednesday. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 08:00 14/01/2026 near Selham, and 20:00 14/01/2026 in Fittleworth. However, on Thursday 20 to 40mm of rain is forecast. River levels are expected to rise again Thursday, with the potential for property flooding. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Including in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. Avoid roads that flood (Iping). 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising slowly today. Flooding may continue on 13 January 2026. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley, Maisemore, Hempstead, Minsterworth Ham and Quedgley. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. Predicted peaks:- Mythe 3.6m to 3.8m on 14/01 AM, Haw Bridge 4.6m to 4.8m on 14/01 AM, Sandhurst 2.9m to 3.1m on 14/01 AM. We are closely monitoring the situation. Further rainfall is forecast for Thursday 15/01. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester
items.message:
Flood alert in force for the River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester 

Flooding is possible for: River Dee in England covers areas around Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington.

River levels remain high today and flooding is still possible on 13 January 2026. 

Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Townfield Lane may potentially be cut off later today.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Flooded drains affect the racecourse & Worcester CCG. PLP should be installed. New St Gate closed at Upton upon Severn. Predicted peaks:- Worcester 3.8m to 4.1m on 13/01 PM, Diglis 3.7m to 3.9m on 13/01 PM, Kempsey Yacht Club 5.9m to 6.1m on 13/01 PM, Saxons Lode 4.3m to 4.6m on 14/01 AM. Other gauge locations are not forecast to exceed Flood Alert thresholds. Further rainfall is forecast on Thursday 15/01. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible in the West Dorset area. Groundwater levels are high in response to heavy rainfall earlier in December. Levels are slowly falling but remain high, and flooding of fields and roads is still possible. Groundwater levels are falling but further rainfall in the coming days may lead to levels rising once more. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 20th January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 13 January.  Flooding is expected to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Kings Bromley to Clay Mills including Burton upon Trent. Further scattered showers are expected throughout today which will cause river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 14 January or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
If you have been evacuated only return to your property once the emergency services have advised that it is safe to do so. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

High river levels this evening may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible on 13 January 2026 and overnight into Wednesday.
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers, particularly in the Abridge area. Property flooding is not expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking river and rainfall levels.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 09:00AM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message:
Rising river levels today may lead to flooding.

Flooding is possible on 13 January 2026.

Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near the River Foulness and the Market Weighton Canal and their tributaries, particularly around Welham Bridge.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 9AM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels are falling. We do not expect further flooding and the flood warning has been removed.  
Rivers and streams remain full due to high groundwater levels and will react rapidly to further rainfall.    
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.    
Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. You are advised to take the opportunity to check any pumps are in good working order and that stocks of sandbags are replenished.
